S Y-L NESENSIELEIER
VOL. XX, NO. 2.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 18, 1915.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

WESTERN MARYLAND DEFEATED IMPORTANT DISCOVERIES MADE

AGREES TO HEAD COMMISSION

SHOWED GOOD POINTS OF TEAM

Black and Blue Rolls Up 35 Points to
Opponent's 12—Game Slow Because of Wet Weather.
Uhler Stars.

Drs. Watson and Lashley, of Psychological Department, Ascertain Effect of
Drugs on Learning Capacity.
Rats are Color Blind.

Pres. Goodnow Accepts Chairmanship
of Efficiency Committee—Finds
Difficulties Which May Hamper Work.

Saturday's Game Revealed the Playing
Ability of Black and Blue Eleven.
Western Maryland Put Up
Splendid Fight.

The, Black and Blue football
team defeated the Western Maryland eleven at Homewood on Saturday, 35 to 12. The up-Staters
put up a game fight to the very end,
but the superiority of the Hopkins
team as a whole told throughout
the contest; the hard, consistent
plunging of the 'Varsity backs,
supported by the excellent work of
the line, left no doubt in the minds
of the spectators as to the outcome
of the contest.
The dariip weather and slow field
rendered open play practically impossible, and the slippery ball was
the cause of several fumbles. Forward passes were successful in
only two instances, and fumbling
throughout the game rendered the
outcome of plays requiring accurate
passing a matter of doubt. This
feature of the game kept the stands
on edge; there were several times
during the contest when the danger
of loss of the ball caused distinct
thrills.
. In spite of the inclement weather
a large crowd was in the stands;
and, although the attendance was
not what had been expected, the
spirit shown by both stands added
life to the affair. Cheering on both
sides was almost uninterrupted, and
the two bands were very much in
evidence. The Hopkins stand did
much better in its cheering than at
the opening game ;- the yells and
songs rang out with true fire,- and
at an especially brilliant play the
noise was deafening.
Scoring began immediately following the kick-off. Bowers caught
the ball, running it io yards, and,
after 2 minutes and 55 seconds of
successful line plunging, Brooks
carried it across the line. Wilkinson kicked a difficult goal. This
was the only scoring done in the
first quarter; the second touchdown
being made by Hoffman i minute
and 50 seconds after the opening ,of
the second period. Shortly before
the end of the quarter, Garrett, of
Western Maryland, tore off on a
spectacular run of 70 yards through
the entire broken field of Hopkins
players and was downed on the
Black and Blue's 5-yard line by
Finney's brilliant tackle. After
four attempts the Green and Gold
scored; Kester failing to kick goal.
In the third quarter, two scores
were made by Hopkins. Uhler
took the ball over both times, and
Practically all of the ground was
gained by line plunging. Wilkinson kicked both goals. In the final
period, each team scored once—

An • important series of experiments, conducted by Prof. John B.
Watson and Dr. K. S. Lashley, both
of the Hopkins psychology department, which has entirely disproved
several old and well-believed theories and has established several
new and rather startling facts, has
been in the process of performance
in the Hopkins laboratories for the
last six or eight months.
The greater part of this work has
gone on in a little room just beneath the steps of the biological laboratory. Here there are stacks of
intricate wire traps, complex mazes
and electrical globes. In a very
tiny room adjoining there are hundreds of crawling, squeaking rats.
These rats have been the subjects
of most of the experiments.
The most recent experiment conducted in these rooms has had for its
purpose the determining of the effect which drugs have upon the rate
of learning. To ascertain this, Mr.
Lashley, who conducted the experiment, fist constructed a wire maze,
corresponding in miniature to the
mazes of Steeple Chase Pier and
Coney Island. The rats were then
divided into groups of ten. An
average was taken of the number
of trials required by the members
of one group after a harmless injection of water to know the way
from the entrance of the maze to
the plate of food which formed its
center. Each rat of another group
was then given a heavy injection of
strychnine, and the -experiment was
repeated.
It was found that the strychnine
nearly doubled the • capacity for
learning: The normal number of
trials required was 43, but under the
influence of the drug the rat was
able to find the food after only 24
attempts. On the other hand, after
an injection of caffeine, an average
of 74.4 trials was required.
Another interesting series of experiments has been conducted by
Professor Watson in the thresholds
of vision of the chick and the rat.
The animal was placed in a closed
box, at the extremity of which lights
were exhibited, and records were
taken of the farthest points at which
the lights were visible to the subject.. Experiments were also undertaken in the distinguishing of
lights of different colors. It was
proved that the chick's threshold
of vision is practically the same as
man's and that he has a color vision,
while the rat is color blind.
These _experiments have been undertaken to ascertain two things:

By COACH CHARLES E. BRICKLEY.
[This is the second of a series of
articles which Mr. Brickley has consented to write for THE NEWS-LETTER,
and in which he will summarize the
main points of each football game from
his standpoint as coach. A more purely
narrative account of the game will be
found elsewhere in this issue—ED.]

President Goodnow has accepted
his appointment to the position of
chairman of the Economy and Efficiency Commission. His acceptance was in the form of a letter to
General Murray Vandiver, chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, in which he stated
that he was greatly interested in the
movement and took great pleasure
in becoming associated with it.
Dr. Goodnow thinks that important work can be accomplished before the meeting of the Legislature,
at which time a commission can be
selected representing the State, and,
armed with the necessary power to
act, to which the present commission can turn over the results of its
work. The present commission, he
says, will work under the difficulty
of lacking authority and funds.
In his letter to General Vandiver,
President Goodnow states that the
above-named difficulties are so serious as to make it probable that the
commission will be unable to do all
of the work expected of it. He
says, regarding the work of the
commission: "If it should fail to
meet public expectations I fear that
the movement for economy and efficiency would be so prejudiced that
it would be seriously retarded, if
not not absolutely arrested."
Many people think that Dr. Goodnow's acceptance of the chairmanship of the commission is one of the
most significant occurrences in the
politics of this State in many
years. To quote from the Sun of
October 17:
•
"The general feeling today
that
Dr. Goodnow, a man who has given
his life to study of the science of
government, is the man to take the
lead in reorganizing the State's
machinery strongly suggests that a
new idea is taking hold of the
people.
"Then, there is Dr. Goodnow's
willingness to work. He could have
found a good many reasons for refusing. He might have backed off
for fear that it would prejudice his
work as president of Hopkins; he
might have declined because the
commission was named by a political party—and it happens that he
has been a Republican in national
affairs. But no! He refused to see
the lions in the way; or, if he saw
them, he. refused to be frightened.
He took hold and,bearing in mind
the high character and the ability
of the other members of the commission the State has assurance that
something real is to be done in
modernizing."

From the standpoint of the
coaches, Saturday's game with
Western Maryland was a very interesting one, as it gave a fine opportunity to size up the ability of
the Hopkins men, playing for the
first time under pressure. It was a
case of Hopkins with a heavier
team playing simple football against
a desperate, fighting eleven with
a varied attack and a good defense,
especially its secondary defense.
Hopkins won by a large score
because its powerful attack was not
to be denied. As I said before,
Western Maryland had a good defense, but it was soon worn out by
the constant tearing and plunging
of the Hopkins backfield. It pleased
Mr. Brennick and myself to see that
the team could make their simple
attack go, for in the games to come
this simple attack will, of course,
give way to a much more varied
one. But I wanted the men to learn
the value of straight, simple football first.
The defensive work•of• the Hopkins team was, on the whole, fair;
considering the variety of their opponent's attack. 'Western Maryland had a well-drilled team and
executed its plays in a clever manner, which made quick thinking on
the part of the defense very essential. With two or three exceptions,
the men sized up the plays of Western Maryland very well. The unfortunate part of it was that the
times they failed to diagnose the
plays resulted practically in touchdowns for the opponents.
Hopkins would have scored at
least two more touchdowns had it
not been for penalties and fumbles.
In both games so far the officials
seemed to delight in penalizing
Hopkins during the early part of
the game, and then in the second
half to exert all their efforts in
penalizing the other teams. As for
fumbles, Saturday was just made
to order. The ball was very slippery and hard to handle; but a
good team must learn to play on a
wet field.
Next Saturday should see great
improvement in every department
of play on the part of Hopkins.
The men have passed through the
very crude period and should now

THE NEWS-LETTER.

That there is every indication
that Yuan Shi Kai, president of the
Chinese republic, may be forced by
the pressure of public opinion in
China to accept the crown and establish a constitutional monarchy
was the opinion expressed by Dr.
D rank J. Goodnow, president of
Johns Hopkins University and constitutional adviser to the Chinese
republic to a representative of THE
NEWS-LETTER on his return from a
three-months' stay in the Orient.
Dr. Goodnow added that it was
impossible to determine the true
trend of public opinion in China, as
the newspapers there were at best
but inadequate recorders of it. In
Peking, however, there is a strong
sentiment in favor of a return to a
monarchial form of government,
while official circles seem to be almost evenly divided with regard to
the proposed plan. The fate of the
Chinese republic is virtually in the
hands of the representative legislature, which will convene next
January to ratify the new constitution.
Dr. Goodnow also declared that
he was strongly in favor of the establishment of some system of military training at Johns Hopkins. He
will, in the near future, confer with
the committee of alumni, who at
present have the matter of instituting a course in military training at
the University under consideration.

In another part of this issue of.
THE NEWS-LETTER reference is
made to the lack of sufficient recognition on the part of freshmen of
the various honors to be striven for
by undergraduate students of Johns
Hopkins. It is unfortunately true
that many first-year men, not fully
realizing the importance and exact
nature of the academic honors attainable during the four years of
college, allow their first year's work
to slip by without making a serious
effort toward high standing, and
thus suffer an irretrievable loss,
which they regret upon becoming
aware of the fact that they did
have the opportunity to distinguish
themselves. THE NEWS - LETTER
hopes, both through the interview
with Dr. French published in this
issue and through this editorial, to
bring the matter before the members of the Class of 1919 in a manner which will cause them to think
seriously of the question, and which
may bring many who had not

Our Advertisers.

THE NEWS-LETTER takes this opportunity to ask every student of
the University to do his buying, as
far as possible, at the shops and
with the firms represented by advertisements in these columns. As
an activity devoted solely to the interests of Hopkins and Hopkins
men, THE NEWS-LETTER is entirely
dependent upon student support for
its existence, and a most important
part of this support consists of
showing the advertisers that it is
worth while for them to pay for
space. This can be done only
through consistent patronage of the
advertisers by the students.
From time to time throughout
the year special inducements in the
form of sales check contests will
be offered in order to make the
patronage of advertisers profitable
to the student. As a matter of fact,
this means of bringing Hopkins
men to support THE NEWS-LETTER
ought not to be necessary; the support should come out of a desire to
do everything possible to make our
activities successful, but the contests for prizes are held notwithstanding for the purpose of creating a more widespread interest in
the matter.
Whenever you are about to make
a purchase of any kind, stop a moment to find out whether it is not
possible for you to get what you
want from a firm advertising in
THE NEWS-LETTER, and if you find
that you can, go to one of the firms
whose name you will find on our
list of advertisers. You will discover that in most cases better satisfaction can be obtained through so
doing, and that in every case you
can get exactly what you want.
Never fail to leave a pink slip with
the salesman. The slips will be distributed among the students at an
early date.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 18, 1915.

The following letter, which explains itself, has been sent to all the
students of the University:
"Sir—The past year has seen a
tremendous awakenirig of interest in
the subject of national preparedness.
The general concensus of opinion
in this regard has been showing itself in the numerous training camps
that have been successfully held
during the past summer, in the formation of defensive leagues and in
the introduction of military training
into various schools and colleges.
The Alumni Association of this
University has been considering the
advisability of recommending to the
faculty and trustees the introduction of the manual of arms into the
University curriculum.
After learning how to handle a
gun, the next step is to learn how
to shoot it! The Johns Hopkins
Rifle and Revolver Club, organized
last spring, has for its chief purpose the instruction of its members
in the use of the United States military rifle.
The aid that we can get from
the State, with regard to arms, ammunition, ranges and instructors,
will vary directly with the number
of men on the club roll. During
the winter, rifle practice will be held
at night in the city armory, while
in the spring the State range not
far from Baltimore will be available
for long-range work. All we need
is a little enthusiasm to produce a
corps of rifle shots that will be a
credit to the University.
For those interested in revolver
shooting, we expect to have the use
of both an indoor and an outdoor
range.
The Johns Hopkins Rifle and
Revolver Association has already,
with the sancition of President
Goodnow, affiliated with the National Rifle Association, as a college
rifle club. This allows us to enter
a team in the college matches
(some score of schools and colleges
compete each year) and in -other
contests held by the National Rifle
Association. We also have the
privilege of purchasing arms and
ammunition from the United States
government at greatly reduced
prices or to borrow arms from the
government under bond. The government will also issue some ammunition free to the members.
This organization has no military
ends, beyond teaching its members
to become proficient in the use of
the military arm. We consider that
object a worthy one and one that
should commend itself to every

Hopkins man.
We want you to come to our first
fall meeting, which will be held in
the Trophy Room on Wednesday,
October 20, at I P. M.
If you are interested and cannot
come to this meeting, please send
your name and address to the secretary.
DR. R. S. CUNNINGHAM,
Secretary,
Johns Hopkins Medical School."

The Sophomore Class held a wellattended meeting on last Thursday
for the purpose of electing officers.
Before the elections, retiring President Frank Sutton spoke of the importance of holding together as a
class. His purpose was to insure
the sophomores' co-operation in enforcing. the new freshman regulations, and in lowering the colors of
freshman athletic teams.
A spirited and well - conducted
election followed, and many candidates for officers were nominated.
The following results of the elections were announced:
President—A. Wolfe.
Vice-President—A. V Hooper.
Secretary—A. K. Chalmers.
Treasurer—R. R. Duncan.
Sergeant-at-Arms—Dodson.
Representative to Student Council—S. Egerton.
After the election, President
Wolfe took the chair and laid out
a plan of campaign for the year,
boding ill for the freshmen.

FALL WORK ON TRACK AND
FIELD BEGUN IN EARNEST

GROUND BROKEN FOR NEW
ENGINEERING BUILDING

Fall work of the track squad has
begun in earnest, and every afternoon finds the cross-country and
field men hard at it at Homewood.
Although the squad is many times
larger than in any previous year,
Captain Hall and Manager Skinner
are making strenuous efforts to considerably increase if and want to
have at least thirty men working
by the end of the week. If the fall
meet which has been planned is to
be a success, this number of men
ought to be out.
There are several new men in
the University who are doing promising work. Riese, a freshman, has
done very good work in the century
event while a student at Towson
High School. Guttmacher, of the
Park School, had had some slight
experience in the half mile.
Sachs, graduate, is a former captain of the Gettysburg track team
and Elmendorf, of the Medical
School, was captain of Rutgers in
1913. There are several other new
men of promise, so that the squad is
as fortunate in this respects as it has
ever been.

Ground was broken for the civil
engineering building at Homewood
last week, when Dr. Charles J.
Tilden, head of the civil engineering department, pulled the lever
that started a steam shovel. The
building will be situated on the
south court, and will probably be
finished by August 15 of next year
—in time for' use when the entire
University is expected to move to
Homewood.
When completed the new structure will be very similar to the mechanical and electrical building, now
the only building in the south court.
It will be 204 feet long and 52 feel
wide and will be three stories high.
There will be one main entrance in
the front, which will face east.
On the first floor there will be a
lecture hall 39 by 65 feet, a departmental library, classrooms and a
number of offices. On the second
floor draughting rooms for seniors,
juniors and graduates will occupy
much of the space, and classrooms
and research rooms will be numerous. On the third floor there will
be a museum in the south end of
the building and plans have been
made for clubrooms in the north
end.

HOPKINS MAN PRESIDENT
OF LACROSSE LEAGUE

At the annual meeting of the
United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse League, which was held in
New York Saturday, October 16,
Milton Erlanger, of Johns Hopkins,
was elected president of the association. Johns Hopkins was represented at the meeting by H. W.
Sutton.
A championship banner will be
awarded to the winning team in
each division, and the players on
the team that wins the championship will receive gold medals. Silver medals will be given to the leading players.
A tentative playing schedule was
drawn up at the meeting for the
season of 1916, but the dates and
places of the games will not be
announced until next year. Playing will begin early in April, and
the final game between the winners of the division championships
will take place during the last week
of May.
Although not as yet a member
of the league, Yale is to be represented by a team this season.

A young lady recently sent this
extraordinary request to the editor
of a weekly journal:
"Do you think it right for a girl
to sit in a man's lap, even if she is
engaged ?"
The editor spent some time in
thought, and then answered her as
follows
"Yes, if it were our girl and our
lap. Yes, again, if it were some
other fellow's girl and our lap. But
if it were our girl and some other
fellow's lap, emphatically no. We
don't approve of such frivolity."

AGREES TO HEAD COMMISSION

SHOWED GOOD POINTS OF TEAM

Black and Blue Rolls Up 35 Points to
Opponent's 12—Game Slow Because of Wet Weather.
Uhler Stars.

Drs. Watson and Lashley, of Psychological Department, Ascertain Effect of
Drugs on Learning Capacity.
Rats are Color Blind.

Pres. Goodnow Accepts Chairmanship
of Efficiency Committee—Finds
Difficulties Which May Hamper Work.

Saturday's Game Revealed the Playing
Ability of Black and Blue Eleven.
Western Maryland Put Up
Splendid Fight.

The, Black and Blue football
team defeated the Western Maryland eleven at Homewood on Saturday, 35 to 12. The up-Staters
put up a game fight to the very end,
but the superiority of the Hopkins
team as a whole told throughout
the contest; the hard, consistent
plunging of the 'Varsity backs,
supported by the excellent work of
the line, left no doubt in the minds
of the spectators as to the outcome
of the contest.
The dariip weather and slow field
rendered open play practically impossible, and the slippery ball was
the cause of several fumbles. Forward passes were successful in
only two instances, and fumbling
throughout the game rendered the
outcome of plays requiring accurate
passing a matter of doubt. This
feature of the game kept the stands
on edge; there were several times
during the contest when the danger
of loss of the ball caused distinct
thrills.
. In spite of the inclement weather
a large crowd was in the stands;
and, although the attendance was
not what had been expected, the
spirit shown by both stands added
life to the affair. Cheering on both
sides was almost uninterrupted, and
the two bands were very much in
evidence. The Hopkins stand did
much better in its cheering than at
the opening game ;- the yells and
songs rang out with true fire,- and
at an especially brilliant play the
noise was deafening.
Scoring began immediately following the kick-off. Bowers caught
the ball, running it io yards, and,
after 2 minutes and 55 seconds of
successful line plunging, Brooks
carried it across the line. Wilkinson kicked a difficult goal. This
was the only scoring done in the
first quarter; the second touchdown
being made by Hoffman i minute
and 50 seconds after the opening ,of
the second period. Shortly before
the end of the quarter, Garrett, of
Western Maryland, tore off on a
spectacular run of 70 yards through
the entire broken field of Hopkins
players and was downed on the
Black and Blue's 5-yard line by
Finney's brilliant tackle. After
four attempts the Green and Gold
scored; Kester failing to kick goal.
In the third quarter, two scores
were made by Hopkins. Uhler
took the ball over both times, and
Practically all of the ground was
gained by line plunging. Wilkinson kicked both goals. In the final
period, each team scored once—

An • important series of experiments, conducted by Prof. John B.
Watson and Dr. K. S. Lashley, both
of the Hopkins psychology department, which has entirely disproved
several old and well-believed theories and has established several
new and rather startling facts, has
been in the process of performance
in the Hopkins laboratories for the
last six or eight months.
The greater part of this work has
gone on in a little room just beneath the steps of the biological laboratory. Here there are stacks of
intricate wire traps, complex mazes
and electrical globes. In a very
tiny room adjoining there are hundreds of crawling, squeaking rats.
These rats have been the subjects
of most of the experiments.
The most recent experiment conducted in these rooms has had for its
purpose the determining of the effect which drugs have upon the rate
of learning. To ascertain this, Mr.
Lashley, who conducted the experiment, fist constructed a wire maze,
corresponding in miniature to the
mazes of Steeple Chase Pier and
Coney Island. The rats were then
divided into groups of ten. An
average was taken of the number
of trials required by the members
of one group after a harmless injection of water to know the way
from the entrance of the maze to
the plate of food which formed its
center. Each rat of another group
was then given a heavy injection of
strychnine, and the -experiment was
repeated.
It was found that the strychnine
nearly doubled the • capacity for
learning: The normal number of
trials required was 43, but under the
influence of the drug the rat was
able to find the food after only 24
attempts. On the other hand, after
an injection of caffeine, an average
of 74.4 trials was required.
Another interesting series of experiments has been conducted by
Professor Watson in the thresholds
of vision of the chick and the rat.
The animal was placed in a closed
box, at the extremity of which lights
were exhibited, and records were
taken of the farthest points at which
the lights were visible to the subject.. Experiments were also undertaken in the distinguishing of
lights of different colors. It was
proved that the chick's threshold
of vision is practically the same as
man's and that he has a color vision,
while the rat is color blind.
These _experiments have been undertaken to ascertain two things:

President Goodnow has accepted
his appointment to the position of
chairman of the Economy and Efficiency Commission. His acceptance was in the form of a letter to
General Murray Vandiver, chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, in which he stated
that he was greatly interested in the
movement and took great pleasure
in becoming associated with it.
Dr. Goodnow thinks that important work can be accomplished before the meeting of the Legislature,
at which time a commission can be
selected representing the State, and,
armed with the necessary power to
act, to which the present commission can turn over the results of its
work. The present commission, he
says, will work under the difficulty
of lacking authority and funds.
In his letter to General Vandiver,
President Goodnow states that the
above-named difficulties are so serious as to make it probable that the
commission will be unable to do all
of the work expected of it. He
says, regarding the work of the
commission: "If it should fail to
meet public expectations I fear that
the movement for economy and efficiency would be so prejudiced that
it would be seriously retarded, if
not not absolutely arrested."
Many people think that Dr. Goodnow's acceptance of the chairmanship of the commission is one of the
most significant occurrences in the
politics of this State in many
years. To quote from the Sun of
October 17:
•
"The general feeling today
that
Dr. Goodnow, a man who has given
his life to study of the science of
government, is the man to take the
lead in reorganizing the State's
machinery strongly suggests that a
new idea is taking hold of the
people.
"Then, there is Dr. Goodnow's
willingness to work. He could have
found a good many reasons for refusing. He might have backed off
for fear that it would prejudice his
work as president of Hopkins; he
might have declined because the
commission was named by a political party—and it happens that he
has been a Republican in national
affairs. But no! He refused to see
the lions in the way; or, if he saw
them, he. refused to be frightened.
He took hold and,bearing in mind
the high character and the ability
of the other members of the commission the State has assurance that
something real is to be done in
modernizing."

From the standpoint of the
coaches, Saturday's game with
Western Maryland was a very interesting one, as it gave a fine opportunity to size up the ability of
the Hopkins men, playing for the
first time under pressure. It was a
case of Hopkins with a heavier
team playing simple football against
a desperate, fighting eleven with
a varied attack and a good defense,
especially its secondary defense.
Hopkins won by a large score
because its powerful attack was not
to be denied. As I said before,
Western Maryland had a good defense, but it was soon worn out by
the constant tearing and plunging
of the Hopkins backfield. It pleased
Mr. Brennick and myself to see that
the team could make their simple
attack go, for in the games to come
this simple attack will, of course,
give way to a much more varied
one. But I wanted the men to learn
the value of straight, simple football first.
The defensive work•of• the Hopkins team was, on the whole, fair;
considering the variety of their opponent's attack. 'Western Maryland had a well-drilled team and
executed its plays in a clever manner, which made quick thinking on
the part of the defense very essential. With two or three exceptions,
the men sized up the plays of Western Maryland very well. The unfortunate part of it was that the
times they failed to diagnose the
plays resulted practically in touchdowns for the opponents.
Hopkins would have scored at
least two more touchdowns had it
not been for penalties and fumbles.
In both games so far the officials
seemed to delight in penalizing
Hopkins during the early part of
the game, and then in the second
half to exert all their efforts in
penalizing the other teams. As for
fumbles, Saturday was just made
to order. The ball was very slippery and hard to handle; but a
good team must learn to play on a
wet field.
Next Saturday should see great
improvement in every department
of play on the part of Hopkins.
The men have passed through the
very crude period and should now

That there is every indication
that Yuan Shi Kai, president of the
Chinese republic, may be forced by
the pressure of public opinion in
China to accept the crown and establish a constitutional monarchy
was the opinion expressed by Dr.
D rank J. Goodnow, president of
Johns Hopkins University and constitutional adviser to the Chinese
republic to a representative of THE
NEWS-LETTER on his return from a
three-months' stay in the Orient.
Dr. Goodnow added that it was
impossible to determine the true
trend of public opinion in China, as
the newspapers there were at best
but inadequate recorders of it. In
Peking, however, there is a strong
sentiment in favor of a return to a
monarchial form of government,
while official circles seem to be almost evenly divided with regard to
the proposed plan. The fate of the
Chinese republic is virtually in the
hands of the representative legislature, which will convene next
January to ratify the new constitution.
Dr. Goodnow also declared that
he was strongly in favor of the establishment of some system of military training at Johns Hopkins. He
will, in the near future, confer with
the committee of alumni, who at
present have the matter of instituting a course in military training at
the University under consideration.

Honors at Johns Hopkins.

In another part of this issue of.
THE NEWS-LETTER reference is
made to the lack of sufficient recognition on the part of freshmen of
the various honors to be striven for
by undergraduate students of Johns
Hopkins. It is unfortunately true
that many first-year men, not fully
realizing the importance and exact
nature of the academic honors attainable during the four years of
college, allow their first year's work
to slip by without making a serious
effort toward high standing, and
thus suffer an irretrievable loss,
which they regret upon becoming
aware of the fact that they did
have the opportunity to distinguish
themselves. THE NEWS - LETTER
hopes, both through the interview
with Dr. French published in this
issue and through this editorial, to
bring the matter before the members of the Class of 1919 in a manner which will cause them to think
seriously of the question, and which
may bring many who had not

Keep Up Your Spirit!

Our Advertisers.

THE NEWS-LETTER takes this opportunity to ask every student of
the University to do his buying, as
far as possible, at the shops and
with the firms represented by advertisements in these columns. As
an activity devoted solely to the interests of Hopkins and Hopkins
men, THE NEWS-LETTER is entirely
dependent upon student support for
its existence, and a most important
part of this support consists of
showing the advertisers that it is
worth while for them to pay for
space. This can be done only
through consistent patronage of the
advertisers by the students.
From time to time throughout
the year special inducements in the
form of sales check contests will
be offered in order to make the
patronage of advertisers profitable
to the student. As a matter of fact,
this means of bringing Hopkins
men to support THE NEWS-LETTER
ought not to be necessary; the support should come out of a desire to
do everything possible to make our
activities successful, but the contests for prizes are held notwithstanding for the purpose of creating a more widespread interest in
the matter.
Whenever you are about to make
a purchase of any kind, stop a moment to find out whether it is not
possible for you to get what you
want from a firm advertising in
THE NEWS-LETTER, and if you find
that you can, go to one of the firms
whose name you will find on our
list of advertisers. You will discover that in most cases better satisfaction can be obtained through so
doing, and that in every case you
can get exactly what you want.
Never fail to leave a pink slip with
the salesman. The slips will be distributed among the students at an
early date.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 18, 1915.

The following letter, which explains itself, has been sent to all the
students of the University:
"Sir—The past year has seen a
tremendous awakenirig of interest in
the subject of national preparedness.
The general concensus of opinion
in this regard has been showing itself in the numerous training camps
that have been successfully held
during the past summer, in the formation of defensive leagues and in
the introduction of military training
into various schools and colleges.
The Alumni Association of this
University has been considering the
advisability of recommending to the
faculty and trustees the introduction of the manual of arms into the
University curriculum.
After learning how to handle a
gun, the next step is to learn how
to shoot it! The Johns Hopkins
Rifle and Revolver Club, organized
last spring, has for its chief purpose the instruction of its members
in the use of the United States military rifle.
The aid that we can get from
the State, with regard to arms, ammunition, ranges and instructors,
will vary directly with the number
of men on the club roll. During
the winter, rifle practice will be held
at night in the city armory, while
in the spring the State range not
far from Baltimore will be available
for long-range work. All we need
is a little enthusiasm to produce a
corps of rifle shots that will be a
credit to the University.
For those interested in revolver
shooting, we expect to have the use
of both an indoor and an outdoor
range.
The Johns Hopkins Rifle and
Revolver Association has already,
with the sancition of President
Goodnow, affiliated with the National Rifle Association, as a college
rifle club. This allows us to enter
a team in the college matches
(some score of schools and colleges
compete each year) and in -other
contests held by the National Rifle
Association. We also have the
privilege of purchasing arms and
ammunition from the United States
government at greatly reduced
prices or to borrow arms from the
government under bond. The government will also issue some ammunition free to the members.
This organization has no military
ends, beyond teaching its members
to become proficient in the use of
the military arm. We consider that
object a worthy one and one that
should commend itself to every

Hopkins man.
We want you to come to our first
fall meeting, which will be held in
the Trophy Room on Wednesday,
October 20, at I P. M.
If you are interested and cannot
come to this meeting, please send
your name and address to the secretary.
DR. R. S. CUNNINGHAM,
Secretary,
Johns Hopkins Medical School."

The Sophomore Class held a wellattended meeting on last Thursday
for the purpose of electing officers.
Before the elections, retiring President Frank Sutton spoke of the importance of holding together as a
class. His purpose was to insure
the sophomores' co-operation in enforcing. the new freshman regulations, and in lowering the colors of
freshman athletic teams.
A spirited and well - conducted
election followed, and many candidates for officers were nominated.
The following results of the elections were announced:
President—A. Wolfe.
Vice-President—A. V Hooper.
Secretary—A. K. Chalmers.
Treasurer—R. R. Duncan.
Sergeant-at-Arms—Dodson.
Representative to Student Council—S. Egerton.
After the election, President
Wolfe took the chair and laid out
a plan of campaign for the year,
boding ill for the freshmen.

FALL WORK ON TRACK AND
FIELD BEGUN IN EARNEST

GROUND BROKEN FOR NEW
ENGINEERING BUILDING

Fall work of the track squad has
begun in earnest, and every afternoon finds the cross-country and
field men hard at it at Homewood.
Although the squad is many times
larger than in any previous year,
Captain Hall and Manager Skinner
are making strenuous efforts to considerably increase if and want to
have at least thirty men working
by the end of the week. If the fall
meet which has been planned is to
be a success, this number of men
ought to be out.
There are several new men in
the University who are doing promising work. Riese, a freshman, has
done very good work in the century
event while a student at Towson
High School. Guttmacher, of the
Park School, had had some slight
experience in the half mile.
Sachs, graduate, is a former captain of the Gettysburg track team
and Elmendorf, of the Medical
School, was captain of Rutgers in
1913. There are several other new
men of promise, so that the squad is
as fortunate in this respects as it has
ever been.

Ground was broken for the civil
engineering building at Homewood
last week, when Dr. Charles J.
Tilden, head of the civil engineering department, pulled the lever
that started a steam shovel. The
building will be situated on the
south court, and will probably be
finished by August 15 of next year
—in time for' use when the entire
University is expected to move to
Homewood.
When completed the new structure will be very similar to the mechanical and electrical building, now
the only building in the south court.
It will be 204 feet long and 52 feel
wide and will be three stories high.
There will be one main entrance in
the front, which will face east.
On the first floor there will be a
lecture hall 39 by 65 feet, a departmental library, classrooms and a
number of offices. On the second
floor draughting rooms for seniors,
juniors and graduates will occupy
much of the space, and classrooms
and research rooms will be numerous. On the third floor there will
be a museum in the south end of
the building and plans have been
made for clubrooms in the north
end.

HOPKINS MAN PRESIDENT
OF LACROSSE LEAGUE

At the annual meeting of the
United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse League, which was held in
New York Saturday, October 16,
Milton Erlanger, of Johns Hopkins,
was elected president of the association. Johns Hopkins was represented at the meeting by H. W.
Sutton.
A championship banner will be
awarded to the winning team in
each division, and the players on
the team that wins the championship will receive gold medals. Silver medals will be given to the leading players.
A tentative playing schedule was
drawn up at the meeting for the
season of 1916, but the dates and
places of the games will not be
announced until next year. Playing will begin early in April, and
the final game between the winners of the division championships
will take place during the last week
of May.
Although not as yet a member
of the league, Yale is to be represented by a team this season.

shop and handed to the assistant
a paper containing some white
powder.
"I say," he said, "what do you
think that is? Just taste it and tell
Ine your opinion."
The grocer smelled it, then
touched it with his tongue.
"Well I should say that was
soda."
"That's just what I said," was
the triumphant reply. "But my wife
said it was rat poison. You might
try it again to make sure."—Ex.

A young lady recently sent this
extraordinary request to the editor
of a weekly journal:
"Do you think it right for a girl
to sit in a man's lap, even if she is
engaged ?"
The editor spent some time in
thought, and then answered her as
follows
"Yes, if it were our girl and our
lap. Yes, again, if it were some
other fellow's girl and our lap. But
if it were our girl and some other
fellow's lap, emphatically no. We
don't approve of such frivolity."
